transcript:
Patient: The behavioral experiment and positive data log didn't go as well as the thought records. I was really nervous about joining the language learning group, so I ended up not going. And I struggled to think of things to write in the positive data log.

Therapist: That's okay, it's common to have some challenges with new techniques. Let's talk through what got in the way with the behavioral experiment. What thoughts were going through your mind when you considered joining the language learning group?

Patient: I guess I was worried that I wouldn't fit in or that people would judge me. I also thought maybe I'm not as good at languages as I think I am, and everyone there would be better than me.

Therapist: Those sound like some of the cognitive distortions we've talked about, like mind reading and comparing yourself to others. Let's break this down a bit. Do you have any evidence that people at the group would judge you?

Patient: Not really, I guess I don't know those people so I can't say for sure what they would think of me. It's more just my own fear.

Therapist: Exactly, that's a great insight. And what about the thought that everyone would be better than you at languages? Is there evidence for that?

Patient: Well, I do have a lot of experience with languages, and I've always done well in language classes. But I guess I was discounting that and assuming everyone else would be experts.

Therapist: That's another great point. It sounds like you might have been falling into the cognitive distortion of disqualifying the positive, where you discount your own strengths and accomplishments. So if we look at this situation objectively, what's an alternative perspective?

Patient: An alternative could be that I have valuable language skills to contribute, and the group could be an opportunity to learn and grow, even if it's challenging at first.

Therapist: Absolutely! I think that's a much more balanced and helpful way to look at it. How about we make attending the language learning group a homework task for this week? You can use the cognitive restructuring techniques we've practiced to challenge any negative thoughts that come up.

Patient: That makes sense, I'm willing to give it another try. I know I need to push myself out of my comfort zone a bit.

Therapist: That's a great attitude to have. And remember, even if it's uncomfortable at first, that doesn't necessarily mean it's bad or that you should avoid it. Let's also talk about the positive data log. What made that challenging?

Patient: I think I struggled to come up with positive things about myself. I'm so used to focusing on my flaws and mistakes.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, especially for people with depression. One thing that can help is to set aside a specific time each day to write in the log, and try to think of just one or two things, even if they seem small. They don't have to be big accomplishments, just anything you did well or felt good about.

Patient: Okay, I can try that. Maybe I could do it before bed each night, and think back on my day.

Therapist: That's a great idea. And remember, the goal is to start building up evidence against those negative core beliefs about yourself. Even small pieces of evidence can add up over time to help shift your overall perspective.

Patient: That makes sense. I'll try to be more consistent with it this week.

Therapist: I'm confident you can do it. Remember, it's okay if it feels challenging at first. The more you practice, the easier it will get. Let's add the positive data log to your homework for this week as well. Do you have any other questions or concerns about the techniques we've discussed today?
